By analogy to influenza, for which children are known to be major transmitters, there was initial concern regarding the potential role of children as ‘silent spreaders’ of SARS-CoV-2,
47

48 and occasional early studies supported this perspective.
49 As SARS-CoV-2 spreads globally, the transmission chains of SARS-CoV-2 are becoming apparent. Collectively, data suggest that children with SARS-CoV-2 acquire their infection from an adult contact, with minimal secondary transmission from children.
50 Droplets are the main mechanism of transmission of SARS-CoV-2, and while some studies have revealed the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA detected in the stool of patients
51 and on environmental surfaces,
52 confirmation of viable virus of sufficient load to produce infection in other individuals has not yet been documented. To date, there are no published data confirming faecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2, despite detectable virus genetic material documented in the stool of paediatric patients.
